name: Landing Zone lens
description: This lens focuses on best practices for designing, implementing, and managing AWS Landing Zones. It addresses key considerations specific to multi-account environments, account lifecycle management, and organizational governance in the context of Landing Zones

questions.title: How do you implement centralized logging across your Landing Zone?
questions.description: Centralized logging is crucial for maintaining visibility and compliance across a multi-account environment. This question addresses how you collect, store, and manage logs from all accounts within your Landing Zone.

choices.title: Route all logs to a dedicated log archive account

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about centralized logging in AWS using CloudWatch Logs and S3

improvementPlan.displayText: Set up a centralized log archive account and configure log routing from all accounts in your organization to this central repository. Use AWS CloudWatch Logs, S3, and Kinesis Data Firehose to implement this logging pipeline.

choices.title: Implement appropriate log retention and lifecycle policies

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore S3 Lifecycle configuration for cost-effective log management

improvementPlan.displayText: Define and implement log retention policies that balance compliance requirements with cost considerations. Use S3 Lifecycle policies to automatically transition logs to cheaper storage classes or delete them after a specified period.

questions.title: How do you manage observability baselines for different Organizational Units (OUs)?
questions.description: Different parts of your organization may have varying observability requirements. This question addresses how you define and implement appropriate observability baselines for different OUs within your Landing Zone.

choices.title: Define OU-specific observability baselines

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Observability best practices

improvementPlan.displayText: Establish distinct observability baselines for each OU, tailoring the level of monitoring (basic or advanced) based on the OU's specific requirements. Document these baselines and review them regularly.

choices.title: Automate the deployment of observability baselines

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS CloudFormation StackSets

improvementPlan.displayText: Use AWS CloudFormation StackSets to automatically deploy and manage observability baselines across accounts within each OU. This ensures consistency and reduces manual effort in maintaining observability configurations.

questions.title: How do you aggregate and visualize metrics across your entire organization?
questions.description: A centralized view of metrics is essential for understanding the overall health and performance of your Landing Zone. This question addresses how you collect and visualize metrics from all accounts in a centralized dashboard.

choices.title: Implement a centralized organizational dashboard

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about cross-account, cross-region dashboards in CloudWatch

improvementPlan.displayText: Create a centralized CloudWatch dashboard that aggregates key metrics from all accounts and regions. Use AWS Organizations and CloudWatch cross-account observability to streamline this process.

choices.title: Automate the collection and aggregation of metrics

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS CloudWatch Metrics Insights

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement automated processes to collect and aggregate metrics from all accounts. Use CloudWatch Metrics Insights for powerful querying capabilities across your entire organization.

questions.title: How do you implement and enforce a tagging strategy across your Landing Zone?
questions.description: A consistent tagging strategy is foundational for cost allocation, resource management, automation, and governance across a multi-account environment. This question addresses how you define, enforce, and maintain tags across all accounts in your Landing Zone.

choices.title: Define an organization-wide tagging policy with mandatory tags

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Organizations tag policies

improvementPlan.displayText: Define a standardized set of mandatory tags (e.g., Environment, Owner, CostCenter, Project) and document them in an organization-wide tagging policy. Use AWS Organizations tag policies to enforce allowed values and consistent casing across all accounts.

choices.title: Enforce tagging compliance using preventive and detective controls

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Config required-tags rule

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement preventive controls using Service Control Policies (SCPs) or IAM policies to deny resource creation without required tags. Deploy detective controls using AWS Config rules (e.g., required-tags) across all accounts via CloudFormation StackSets to identify non-compliant resources.

choices.title: Automate tag remediation and reporting

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Resource Groups Tag Editor

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement automated remediation for untagged or incorrectly tagged resources using AWS Config auto-remediation with AWS Systems Manager or Lambda. Use AWS Resource Groups Tag Editor and Cost Allocation Tags to generate regular compliance reports and track tagging coverage.

choices.title: Establish a tagging governance lifecycle with regular reviews

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS tagging best practices

improvementPlan.displayText: Establish a governance process to regularly review and update your tagging strategy. Include stakeholders from finance, security, and operations to ensure tags remain aligned with organizational needs. Track tagging compliance metrics over time and incorporate tagging requirements into account vending processes.

questions.title: How do you implement centralized patch management across your Landing Zone?
questions.description: Consistent and timely patching is critical for maintaining the security and stability of workloads across a multi-account environment. This question addresses how you centralize, automate, and monitor patch management across all accounts in your Landing Zone.

choices.title: Define and enforce patch baselines across the organization

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager

improvementPlan.displayText: Define patch baselines in AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager for each operating system and application type used across your organization. Use AWS Organizations and CloudFormation StackSets to deploy consistent patch baselines to all accounts.

choices.title: Automate patch deployment using maintenance windows

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Systems Manager Maintenance Windows

improvementPlan.displayText: Configure AWS Systems Manager Maintenance Windows to automate patch deployment across all accounts. Define schedules that align with your change management processes and use patching orchestration to minimize downtime.

choices.title: Implement centralized patch compliance reporting

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about Systems Manager compliance reporting

improvementPlan.displayText: Use AWS Systems Manager Compliance to aggregate patch compliance data from all accounts into a centralized view. Configure AWS Config rules to detect unpatched instances and set up dashboards to track patch compliance across the organization.

choices.title: Automate detection and remediation of non-compliant instances

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Config auto-remediation

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement automated remediation workflows using AWS Config auto-remediation and AWS Systems Manager Automation runbooks to automatically patch non-compliant instances. Set up alerts for instances that remain non-compliant after remediation attempts.

questions.title: How do you use AWS Service Catalog to standardize resource provisioning across your Landing Zone?
questions.description: AWS Service Catalog enables organizations to provide self-service access to approved, pre-configured resources while maintaining governance and compliance. This question addresses how you use Service Catalog to standardize and govern resource provisioning across all accounts in your Landing Zone.

choices.title: Create and manage portfolios of approved products

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Service Catalog portfolios

improvementPlan.displayText: Create Service Catalog portfolios containing approved CloudFormation or Terraform templates for common infrastructure patterns (e.g., VPCs, databases, compute). Organize products by team function or workload type to simplify discovery.

choices.title: Share portfolios across the organization using AWS Organizations

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about sharing Service Catalog portfolios

improvementPlan.displayText: Share Service Catalog portfolios across your AWS Organization or specific OUs so that all accounts have access to approved products. Use organizational sharing to automatically make portfolios available to new accounts.

choices.title: Apply launch constraints and governance controls to products

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore Service Catalog constraints

improvementPlan.displayText: Apply launch constraints to control the IAM role used when provisioning products, ensuring least privilege. Use template constraints to limit configurable parameters and tag update constraints to enforce tagging standards on provisioned resources.

choices.title: Implement product versioning and lifecycle management

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about managing Service Catalog products

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement version management for Service Catalog products with a CI/CD pipeline to test and publish updates. Deprecate outdated versions and notify teams to upgrade. Track provisioned product usage to identify and retire unused products.

questions.title: How do you ensure resource backup policies are enforced across all accounts, new and existing?
questions.description: A centralized backup strategy is essential for data protection and disaster recovery across a multi-account environment. This question addresses how you define, deploy, and enforce backup policies across all accounts in your Landing Zone, ensuring both new and existing accounts are covered.

choices.title: Define and enforce backup policies using AWS Organizations backup policies

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Organizations backup policies

improvementPlan.displayText: Enable backup policies in AWS Organizations and define organization-level backup plans that automatically apply to all member accounts, including newly created ones. Specify backup frequency, retention periods, and target resource types.

choices.title: Centralize backup management using AWS Backup with cross-account management

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Backup cross-account management

improvementPlan.displayText: Configure AWS Backup with a delegated administrator account to centrally manage backup plans, vaults, and policies across all accounts. Use cross-account backup to copy backups to a centralized vault for additional protection.

choices.title: Monitor backup compliance and detect unprotected resources

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Backup Audit Manager

improvementPlan.displayText: Use AWS Backup Audit Manager to create audit frameworks that continuously evaluate backup compliance across all accounts. Deploy AWS Config rules (e.g., backup-plan-min-frequency-and-min-retention-check) to detect resources that are not covered by a backup plan.

choices.title: Regularly test backup restoration and validate recovery procedures

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Backup restore testing

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement automated restore testing using AWS Backup restore testing plans to regularly validate that backups can be successfully restored. Document recovery procedures and track recovery time objectives (RTO) and recovery point objectives (RPO) across the organization.

questions.title: How do you maintain a centralized resource inventory across all accounts in your Landing Zone?
questions.description: A comprehensive resource inventory is essential for governance, cost management, security posture assessment, and operational visibility across a multi-account environment. This question addresses how you use AWS Config and related services to discover, track, and query all resources across your organization.

choices.title: Enable AWS Config recording across all accounts and Regions

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Config multi-account, multi-Region data aggregation

improvementPlan.displayText: Enable AWS Config recorders in all accounts and all governed Regions using CloudFormation StackSets or AWS Control Tower. Record all supported resource types to maintain a complete inventory of your AWS resources.

choices.title: Deploy an organization-level Config aggregator for centralized visibility

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Config aggregators

improvementPlan.displayText: Create an organization-level AWS Config aggregator in a centralized account to collect configuration and compliance data from all member accounts and Regions into a single view.

choices.title: Use AWS Config advanced queries for resource discovery and reporting

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Config advanced queries

improvementPlan.displayText: Use AWS Config advanced queries (SQL-based) to search and filter resources across your entire organization. Build queries for common inventory needs such as listing all public-facing resources, untagged resources, or resources by type and Region.

choices.title: Automate inventory reporting and drift detection

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Config conformance packs

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement automated inventory reports using Config advanced queries and Lambda to generate regular resource inventories. Use Config rules and conformance packs to detect configuration drift and unauthorized resource deployments across the organization.

questions.title: How do you centralize AWS Health notifications across your Landing Zone?
questions.description: AWS Health provides visibility into service events, scheduled maintenance, and account-specific issues that may affect your workloads. This question addresses how you aggregate, monitor, and act on health notifications across all accounts in your organization.

choices.title: Enable AWS Health organizational view

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Health organizational view

improvementPlan.displayText: Enable the AWS Health organizational view from your management account to aggregate health events from all member accounts into a single centralized view. This provides visibility into service disruptions and maintenance events across your entire organization.

choices.title: Automate health event notifications using Amazon EventBridge

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about monitoring AWS Health events with EventBridge

improvementPlan.displayText: Configure Amazon EventBridge rules to capture AWS Health events and route notifications to appropriate channels (e.g., SNS topics, Slack, PagerDuty). Set up rules for different event types to ensure the right teams are notified about relevant health events.

choices.title: Implement a centralized health notification dashboard

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Health Dashboard

improvementPlan.displayText: Build a centralized health dashboard using AWS Health API data, CloudWatch, or third-party tools to provide a single pane of glass for all health events across the organization. Include historical event tracking and impact analysis.

choices.title: Automate responses to critical health events

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Health Aware

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement automated response workflows using EventBridge, Lambda, and Systems Manager to take action on critical health events. For example, automatically failover resources during service disruptions or create incident tickets for scheduled maintenance windows.

questions.title: How do you manage alternate contacts across all accounts in your Landing Zone?
questions.description: AWS alternate contacts (billing, operations, security) ensure that the right people receive important notifications from AWS. This question addresses how you automate the configuration and maintenance of alternate contacts across all accounts, including newly created ones.

choices.title: Define standard alternate contacts for all account types

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS account alternate contacts

improvementPlan.displayText: Define standard alternate contacts (billing, operations, security) for each account type or OU. Use distribution lists or shared mailboxes rather than individual email addresses to ensure continuity when team members change.

choices.title: Automate alternate contact configuration for new accounts

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore the AWS Account Management API

improvementPlan.displayText: Integrate alternate contact configuration into your account vending process using the AWS Account Management API (PutAlternateContact). Ensure that every new account is automatically provisioned with the correct billing, operations, and security contacts.

choices.title: Monitor and enforce alternate contact compliance across existing accounts

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Config custom rules

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement a periodic audit using Lambda and the Account Management API to verify that all accounts have the correct alternate contacts configured. Use AWS Config custom rules or scheduled scripts to detect and report accounts with missing or outdated contacts.

choices.title: Establish a lifecycle process for reviewing and updating contacts

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Organizations account management

improvementPlan.displayText: Establish a regular review cycle (e.g., quarterly) to validate that alternate contacts remain accurate. Implement automated notifications when team changes occur and integrate contact updates into your organizational change management processes.

questions.title: How do you implement a centralized IAM Identity Center?
questions.description: A centralized IAM Identity Center (IdC) instance is essential for managing user access across your Landing Zone. This question addresses how you implement and manage a centralized IdC instance across all accounts in your Landing Zone.

choices.title: Implement a centralized IdC instance

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS IAM Identity Center

improvementPlan.displayText: Set up a centralized IdC instance in your management account and configure AWS IAM Identity Center to manage user access across all accounts in your organization. Use AWS Organizations integration to streamline this process.

choices.title: Automate IdC permission set and account assignment management

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS CloudFormation for IAM Identity Center

improvementPlan.displayText: Use AWS CloudFormation or AWS CDK to automate the creation and management of permission sets and account assignments in IAM Identity Center. This ensures consistency and reduces manual effort in maintaining IdC configurations across your organization.

questions.title: What is your identity and access management strategy across your Landing Zone?
questions.description: A well-defined IAM strategy is fundamental to securing a multi-account environment. This question addresses whether you use federated or native IAM users, which Identity Provider (IdP) you employ for managing identities outside of AWS, and how you federate AWS accounts with your IdP (individually per account or centrally via AWS IAM Identity Center).

choices.title: Using native IAM users in individual accounts

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about IAM users and best practices

improvementPlan.displayText: Native IAM users in individual accounts create management overhead and security risks at scale. Plan a migration to federated access using an external Identity Provider integrated with AWS IAM Identity Center to centralize identity management.

choices.title: Federated access configured individually per account with an external IdP

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about IAM identity providers and federation

improvementPlan.displayText: Per-account federation with an external IdP (e.g., Okta, Azure AD, Ping Identity) provides federated access but creates management complexity as accounts grow. Migrate to AWS IAM Identity Center for centralized federation across all accounts via a single integration point.

choices.title: Centralized federation via AWS IAM Identity Center with an external IdP

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about connecting an external IdP to IAM Identity Center

improvementPlan.displayText: You have centralized federation through IAM Identity Center integrated with an external IdP. Ensure you have automated provisioning (SCIM) enabled, permission sets aligned with least privilege, and regular access reviews in place.

choices.title: Implement IAM governance with automated access reviews and least privilege enforcement

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore IAM Access Analyzer for policy validation

improvementPlan.displayText: Complement your federation strategy with IAM Access Analyzer to identify unused access and overly permissive policies. Implement automated access reviews, enforce MFA for all human identities, and use SCPs to prevent creation of native IAM users in member accounts.

questions.title: How do you implement centralized compliance management?
questions.description: Centralized compliance management is essential for maintaining consistent compliance standards across your Landing Zone. This question addresses how you implement and manage compliance across all accounts in your Landing Zone.

choices.title: Establish a centralized compliance team with defined processes

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Audit Manager

improvementPlan.displayText: Establish a centralized compliance team with clearly defined roles and responsibilities. Implement AWS Audit Manager to continuously audit your AWS usage and prepare for assessments. Develop standardized processes for compliance monitoring, reporting, and remediation across all accounts.

choices.title: Automate compliance monitoring and reporting

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Config and AWS Security Hub

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement AWS Config to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources. Use AWS Security Hub to automate security checks and centralize security alerts. Leverage AWS CloudFormation StackSets or AWS Control Tower to consistently deploy these services and custom rules across all accounts in your organization.

choices.title: Integrate compliance into CI/CD pipelines

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about DevSecOps on AWS

improvementPlan.displayText: Integrate compliance checks into your CI/CD pipelines using tools like AWS CodePipeline and AWS Config rules. Implement policy-as-code using tools like AWS CloudFormation Guard or Open Policy Agent to ensure that all deployed resources meet compliance standards before they reach production.

questions.title: How do you manage compliance standards across your Landing Zone?
questions.description: Compliance is a critical aspect of many organizations' IT governance. This question addresses how you implement, manage, and enforce compliance standards across your Landing Zone, ensuring that different accounts meet their specific compliance requirements.

choices.title: Classify accounts based on compliance requirements

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Config for compliance management

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement a tagging strategy to classify accounts based on their compliance requirements. Use these tags to drive automated compliance checks and service restrictions.

choices.title: Implement compliance controls in the Landing Zone

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Control Tower for governance and compliance

improvementPlan.displayText: Use AWS Control Tower or custom solutions to implement baseline compliance controls across your Landing Zone. Regularly review and update these controls to ensure they meet evolving compliance requirements.

choices.title: Enforce service restrictions based on compliance standards

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Organizations Service Control Policies

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement Service Control Policies (SCPs) that deny access to specific AWS services based on an account's compliance classification. Regularly review and update these policies to ensure they align with current compliance requirements and organizational needs.

questions.title: How do you manage data classification across your Landing Zone?
questions.description: Proper data classification is crucial for maintaining security, compliance, and appropriate access controls. This question addresses how you identify, categorize, and manage different types of data across your Landing Zone accounts.

choices.title: Implement a data classification schema

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS data classification best practices

improvementPlan.displayText: Develop and implement a clear data classification schema that includes categories such as PII, Customer Data, Intellectual Property (IP), and Non-Classified Data. Document this schema and ensure it's communicated across the organization.

choices.title: Classify accounts based on data sensitivity

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Organizations and account management

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement a tagging strategy to classify accounts based on the most sensitive data they contain (e.g., PII, Customer Data, IP, Non-Classified). Use these tags to drive automated security controls and access policies.

choices.title: Enforce data handling policies based on classification

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM)

improvementPlan.displayText: Develop and implement IAM policies and Service Control Policies (SCPs) that enforce appropriate data handling practices based on account classification. This should include access restrictions, encryption requirements, and data transfer policies.

choices.title: Implement automated data discovery and classification

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore Amazon Macie for data discovery and classification

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement automated data discovery and classification tools like Amazon Macie across your accounts. Regularly scan for sensitive data to ensure it's properly classified and protected, and to identify any misplaced sensitive information.

questions.title: How do you implement and maintain automated incident response across your Landing Zone?
questions.description: Automated incident response is crucial for maintaining the security and operational integrity of your Landing Zone. This question addresses how you implement and automatically deploy incident response mechanisms across all accounts, including newly created ones.

choices.title: Establish a centralized incident response setup

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Systems Manager Incident Manager

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement AWS Systems Manager Incident Manager in a centralized security account. Configure it to integrate with AWS Security Hub and other security services across your organization.

choices.title: Automate incident response deployment to new accounts

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS CloudFormation StackSets

improvementPlan.displayText: Use AWS CloudFormation StackSets or AWS Control Tower Customizations to automatically deploy incident response configurations, including necessary IAM roles and AWS Config rules, to all new accounts upon creation.

choices.title: Develop and maintain incident response playbooks

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about Incident Manager response plans

improvementPlan.displayText: Create standardized incident response playbooks using Incident Manager response plans. Ensure these playbooks are automatically associated with new accounts and regularly updated to address evolving threats.

choices.title: Regularly test and refine incident response procedures

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Fault Injection Simulator

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement a regular testing schedule using AWS Fault Injection Simulator to simulate incidents and validate your automated response procedures. Use insights from these tests to continuously improve your incident response capabilities.

questions.title: How do you manage emergency access across your Landing Zone?
questions.description: Emergency access mechanisms, such as break glass accounts, are essential for maintaining operational continuity in critical situations. This question addresses how you implement and manage emergency access across all accounts in your Landing Zone, including newly created ones.

choices.title: Establish a dedicated break glass account

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS account best practices

improvementPlan.displayText: Create a dedicated break glass account with highly privileged, emergency-use-only credentials. Implement strict security controls and monitoring on this account.

choices.title: Automate emergency access to new accounts

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Organizations APIs

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement an automated process using AWS Lambda and AWS Organizations APIs to ensure the break glass account automatically gains necessary access to any newly created account in the Landing Zone.

choices.title: Implement regular access reviews for emergency credentials

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS IAM Access Analyzer

improvementPlan.displayText: Use AWS IAM Access Analyzer to regularly review and audit access patterns of the break glass account. Implement automated processes to revoke unnecessary permissions and ensure the principle of least privilege is maintained.

choices.title: Establish and maintain emergency access processes

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Secrets Manager

improvementPlan.displayText: Develop clear processes for using emergency access, including approval workflows and post-incident reviews. Store emergency credentials securely using AWS Secrets Manager with strict access controls and rotation policies.

questions.title: How do you manage CloudTrail log storage and retention across your Landing Zone?
questions.description: CloudTrail provides a comprehensive audit trail of API activity across your AWS environment. This question addresses how you store, centralize, and ensure completeness of CloudTrail log data across all accounts and regions in your Landing Zone.

choices.title: CloudTrail logs are stored in a single account and region

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS CloudTrail

improvementPlan.displayText: You have a basic CloudTrail setup in a single account and region. To improve, configure an organization trail that delivers logs from all accounts and regions to a centralized, dedicated log archive account.

choices.title: CloudTrail logs are stored in a centralized account in one region

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about creating an organization trail

improvementPlan.displayText: You have centralized CloudTrail log storage, which is a good foundation. Ensure that all accounts and all regions are covered by enabling an organization trail, and implement automated detection to identify accounts or regions that may not be sending logs.

choices.title: CloudTrail logs are in a centralized account but not all accounts are configured

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Config rules for CloudTrail compliance

improvementPlan.displayText: Ensure complete coverage by enabling an AWS Organizations trail that automatically applies to all member accounts. Use AWS Config rules such as 'cloudtrail-enabled' to detect accounts that are not properly configured and remediate gaps.

choices.title: All accounts and regions are covered with automatic detection and remediation

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS CloudTrail Lake for centralized querying

improvementPlan.displayText: You have comprehensive CloudTrail coverage with automated detection and remediation. Continue to review and refine your setup by leveraging CloudTrail Lake for centralized querying and analysis, and ensure log integrity validation is enabled.

questions.title: How do you enforce the use of approved AMIs (Golden Images) for EC2 instances across your Landing Zone?
questions.description: Using approved, hardened AMIs ensures that EC2 instances are launched with a consistent, secure baseline. This question addresses how you create, distribute, and enforce the use of golden images across all accounts in your Landing Zone.

choices.title: Implement an automated golden AMI build pipeline

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about EC2 Image Builder

improvementPlan.displayText: Use EC2 Image Builder to create automated pipelines that build, test, and publish hardened AMIs. Include security benchmarks (e.g., CIS) and required agents in the image recipes, and schedule regular rebuilds to incorporate the latest patches.

choices.title: Centrally share approved AMIs across the organization

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about sharing AMIs with AWS Organizations

improvementPlan.displayText: Share approved AMIs from a centralized account to all member accounts using AWS Organizations integration or AWS RAM. Maintain a catalog of approved AMIs and ensure new versions are automatically distributed.

choices.title: Enforce the use of approved AMIs via preventive controls

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Config approved-amis-by-id rule

improvementPlan.displayText: Use AWS Config rules (approved-amis-by-id or approved-amis-by-tag) to detect EC2 instances launched from unapproved AMIs. Complement with IAM policies or SCPs that restrict ec2:RunInstances to only approved AMI IDs or tags.

choices.title: Implement AMI lifecycle management with deprecation and rotation

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AMI deprecation

improvementPlan.displayText: Establish a lifecycle process for golden AMIs that includes versioning, deprecation of older images, and automated notifications to account owners when they are running instances on deprecated AMIs. Use AMI deprecation features to prevent new launches from outdated images.

questions.title: How do you prevent the provisioning of resources in prohibited AWS Regions?
questions.description: Restricting resource provisioning to approved AWS Regions is essential for data sovereignty, regulatory compliance, and reducing your attack surface. This question addresses how you define, enforce, and monitor region restrictions across all accounts in your Landing Zone.

choices.title: Enforce region restrictions using Service Control Policies (SCPs)

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about SCPs to restrict AWS Regions

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement SCPs that deny all actions in non-approved AWS Regions. Apply these policies at the appropriate OU level to ensure all member accounts are restricted. Include exemptions only for global services (e.g., IAM, CloudFront, Route 53) that must operate across regions.

choices.title: Use AWS Control Tower region deny guardrails

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Control Tower Region deny setting

improvementPlan.displayText: If using AWS Control Tower, enable the Region deny setting to automatically restrict resource provisioning to your governed Regions. This provides a managed approach that stays updated with global service exemptions.

choices.title: Monitor for resources deployed in unauthorized Regions

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Config multi-Region, multi-account data aggregation

improvementPlan.displayText: Deploy AWS Config aggregators across all Regions to detect any resources that may have been provisioned in unauthorized Regions. Set up alerts and automated remediation to address any violations promptly.

choices.title: Establish a governed exception process for Region access

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Organizations policy management

improvementPlan.displayText: Define a formal exception process for teams that require access to additional Regions. Include approval workflows, time-bound access, and audit trails. Use OU-level SCPs to grant Region access only to specific accounts that have been approved through this process.

questions.title: Do you have a security baseline automatically applied to all accounts in your Landing Zone?
questions.description: A security baseline ensures that every account, including newly provisioned ones, has essential security services enabled from day one. This question addresses how you automatically deploy and maintain services such as GuardDuty, Security Hub, AWS Config, and VPC Flow Logs across all accounts.

choices.title: Enable Amazon GuardDuty across all accounts automatically

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about GuardDuty multi-account management

improvementPlan.displayText: Enable GuardDuty in a delegated administrator account and configure it to automatically enroll all existing and new member accounts. Centralize findings to a security account for monitoring and response.

choices.title: Enable AWS Security Hub across all accounts with security standards

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about Security Hub multi-account management

improvementPlan.displayText: Enable Security Hub in a delegated administrator account with auto-enable for new accounts. Activate relevant security standards (e.g., AWS Foundational Security Best Practices, CIS Benchmarks) and centralize findings for organization-wide visibility.

choices.title: Enable VPC Flow Logs and AWS Config across all accounts

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about VPC Flow Logs

improvementPlan.displayText: Use CloudFormation StackSets or AWS Control Tower customizations to automatically deploy VPC Flow Logs and AWS Config recorders in every account. Route flow logs to a centralized logging account for analysis and retention.

choices.title: Implement automated drift detection and remediation for the security baseline

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Config conformance packs

improvementPlan.displayText: Deploy AWS Config conformance packs to continuously monitor that all baseline security services remain enabled. Implement automated remediation using Config auto-remediation and Systems Manager Automation to re-enable any services that are disabled or misconfigured.

questions.title: Do you have standard default security group rules applied to all VPCs across your organization?
questions.description: The default security group in every VPC allows unrestricted inbound traffic from itself and all outbound traffic by default. Standardizing and locking down default security group rules across all accounts is essential to prevent unintended network exposure. This question addresses how you manage and enforce security group baselines across your Landing Zone.

choices.title: Restrict the default security group in all VPCs to deny all traffic

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about restricting default security groups

improvementPlan.displayText: Modify the default security group in all VPCs to remove all inbound and outbound rules, effectively denying all traffic. Use CloudFormation StackSets or Control Tower customizations to enforce this configuration on all existing and new accounts.

choices.title: Deploy standardized security group templates to all accounts

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore CloudFormation StackSets for multi-account deployment

improvementPlan.displayText: Create a set of standardized security group templates (e.g., web tier, application tier, database tier) and deploy them to all accounts using CloudFormation StackSets. Ensure teams use these pre-approved security groups instead of creating ad-hoc rules.

choices.title: Detect and alert on non-compliant security group configurations

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Config rules for security groups

improvementPlan.displayText: Deploy AWS Config rules (e.g., vpc-default-security-group-closed, restricted-common-ports) across all accounts to continuously detect security groups that allow unrestricted access or use the default security group. Centralize findings in Security Hub.

choices.title: Automate remediation of non-compliant security groups

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Config auto-remediation

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement AWS Config auto-remediation using Systems Manager Automation runbooks to automatically revert non-compliant security group changes. Ensure the default security group is locked down and any unauthorized modifications are automatically corrected.

questions.title: How do you monitor and manage costs across your AWS organization?
questions.description: Effective cost monitoring and management are crucial for maintaining financial control over your AWS environment. This question addresses how you implement cost visibility and management tools across your organization, ensuring that stakeholders at every level have access to relevant cost information.

choices.title: Implement a comprehensive cost dashboard

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Cost Explorer and CUDOS

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement a centralized cost dashboard using tools like AWS Cost Explorer or CUDOS (Cost and Usage Data Open Source). Ensure the dashboard provides detailed breakdowns of costs by account, service, and tag, allowing for granular analysis.

choices.title: Align cost reporting with organizational structure

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Organizations and cost allocation tags

improvementPlan.displayText: Configure your cost dashboard to reflect your AWS Organizations structure. Use cost allocation tags and account groupings to ensure that costs are associated with the correct organizational units, allowing stakeholders to view costs for the accounts they're responsible for.

choices.title: Implement role-based access to cost data

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about IAM policies for AWS Cost Management

improvementPlan.displayText: Set up IAM roles and policies to provide appropriate access to cost data based on organizational hierarchy. Ensure that users can only view cost information for the accounts and resources they are responsible for.

choices.title: Set up automated cost reporting and alerting

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Budgets

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement AWS Budgets to set up cost thresholds and automated alerts. Configure regular cost reports to be sent to relevant stakeholders, providing ongoing visibility into spending patterns and potential cost anomalies.

questions.title: How do you manage costs and lifecycles for sandbox environments in your Landing Zone?
questions.description: Sandbox environments are crucial for innovation and testing, but they can also lead to unexpected costs if not properly managed. This question addresses how you implement, control, and govern sandbox accounts within your Landing Zone to balance innovation with cost management.

choices.title: Implement a dedicated Sandbox Organizational Unit (OU)

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Organizations and OUs

improvementPlan.displayText: Create a dedicated Sandbox OU within your AWS Organization. Apply specific policies and guardrails to this OU to ensure appropriate governance of sandbox environments.

choices.title: Implement automated budgets for each sandbox account

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Budgets

improvementPlan.displayText: Develop an automated process to create and apply AWS Budgets to each new sandbox account. Set up alerts to notify account owners and administrators when spending approaches the budget limit.

choices.title: Enforce time limitations on sandbox accounts

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Config Rules

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement a mechanism to track the age of sandbox accounts, such as using tags and AWS Config Rules. Set a policy to review or automatically decommission sandbox accounts after a set period (e.g., 3 months).

choices.title: Automatically delete accounts exceeding limits

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Lambda for automation

improvementPlan.displayText: Develop an automated process using AWS Lambda and Step Functions to monitor sandbox accounts for budget or time limit violations. Implement a workflow to automatically back up essential data and delete accounts that exceed these limits.

questions.title: How do you centrally manage the procurement and usage of third-party software across your AWS organization?
questions.description: Effective management of third-party software procurement, licensing, and usage is crucial for cost control and compliance in a multi-account environment. This question addresses how you centralize and optimize the management of third-party software across your AWS organization.

choices.title: Use AWS Private Marketplace for centralized software procurement

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Marketplace Private Marketplace

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement AWS Private Marketplace to create a curated list of approved third-party software products. Configure approval workflows to manage and control software purchases across your organization, ensuring compliance with procurement policies and budget constraints.

choices.title: Implement AWS License Manager for license tracking

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS License Manager

improvementPlan.displayText: Deploy AWS License Manager to track and manage software licenses across your AWS organization. Set up license rules and automate license usage tracking to optimize costs and ensure compliance with licensing terms.

choices.title: Use AWS Systems Manager Inventory for software discovery

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Systems Manager Inventory

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement AWS Systems Manager Inventory across all accounts in your organization to automatically discover and track installed software on EC2 instances and on-premises servers. Use this data to identify unauthorized or underutilized software and optimize licensing costs.

choices.title: Implement software cost optimization processes

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Cost Optimization

improvementPlan.displayText: Develop processes to regularly review software usage data from License Manager and Systems Manager Inventory. Use this information to optimize software licenses, remove unused software, and negotiate better terms with vendors based on actual usage patterns.

questions.title: How have you designed your AWS Organization structure to optimize performance and resource management?
questions.description: The structure of your AWS Organization can significantly impact the efficiency of resource deployment, policy management, and overall performance of your Landing Zone. This question addresses how you've organized your accounts to balance control, resource sharing, and operational efficiency.

choices.title: Group accounts based on common controls

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Organizations and Service Control Policies

improvementPlan.displayText: Reorganize your AWS Organization structure to group accounts with similar control requirements into the same Organizational Units (OUs). This allows for more efficient application of Service Control Policies (SCPs) and simplifies governance.

choices.title: Group accounts based on common resources for mass deployment

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS CloudFormation StackSets

improvementPlan.displayText: Restructure your AWS Organization to group accounts that share similar resource requirements. This facilitates efficient mass deployment of resources using tools like AWS CloudFormation StackSets or AWS Proton, improving performance and reducing management overhead.

choices.title: Implement a hybrid approach combining control and resource-based grouping

helpfulResource.displayText: Best practices for AWS Organizations

improvementPlan.displayText: Design a multi-level OU structure that balances both control requirements and resource deployment needs. Use top-level OUs for broad control categories, and sub-OUs for resource-based groupings. This approach provides flexibility while maintaining efficient governance and resource management.

questions.title: How do you manage network connectivity for new accounts in your Landing Zone?
questions.description: Efficient network design and connectivity are crucial for performance and security in a multi-account environment. This question addresses how you handle network connectivity for newly created accounts within your Landing Zone, ensuring appropriate isolation or integration as required.

choices.title: Implement selective network connectivity based on account classification

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about AWS Transit Gateway

improvementPlan.displayText: Develop a classification system for accounts based on their connectivity requirements. Use AWS Organizations tags or custom metadata to identify accounts that need network connectivity. Implement AWS Transit Gateway or AWS Cloud WAN to connect only the identified accounts.

choices.title: Automate network connectivity for identified accounts

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Network Manager

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement an automated process using AWS Lambda and AWS Network Manager to detect newly created accounts that require connectivity (based on tags or metadata). Automatically attach these accounts to the appropriate Transit Gateway or Cloud WAN, and configure necessary route tables and security groups.

choices.title: Maintain default network isolation for new accounts

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about VPC best practices

improvementPlan.displayText: Implement a default policy of network isolation for all new accounts. Ensure that VPCs in new accounts are created without direct connectivity to other accounts or on-premises networks by default, requiring explicit action to enable connectivity.

choices.title: Implement comprehensive network monitoring and logging

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore AWS Network Firewall

improvementPlan.displayText: Deploy AWS Network Firewall or third-party network monitoring tools to monitor traffic across account boundaries. Implement VPC Flow Logs and centralize logging to maintain visibility into network traffic patterns and potential security issues.

questions.title: How do you manage IP address allocation (IPAM) and CIDR ranges across your organization?
questions.description: Effective IP address management is critical for avoiding CIDR conflicts, enabling seamless network connectivity, and scaling your multi-account environment. This question addresses how you plan, allocate, and govern IP address space across all accounts and VPCs in your Landing Zone.

choices.title: Use Amazon VPC IPAM for centralized IP address management

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about Amazon VPC IPAM

improvementPlan.displayText: Deploy Amazon VPC IPAM with an organization-level delegated administrator. Create IPAM pools with defined CIDR ranges for each environment (production, staging, sandbox) and Region. Use IPAM to automatically allocate non-overlapping CIDRs to new VPCs.

choices.title: Automate CIDR allocation for new accounts and VPCs

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore IPAM integration with AWS Organizations

improvementPlan.displayText: Integrate IPAM with your account vending process so that new accounts and VPCs automatically receive CIDR allocations from the appropriate pool. Use CloudFormation or CDK to provision VPCs with IPAM-allocated CIDRs, preventing manual errors and overlaps.

choices.title: Monitor for CIDR conflicts and non-compliant allocations

helpfulResource.displayText: Learn about IPAM monitoring and compliance

improvementPlan.displayText: Use IPAM compliance features to detect overlapping CIDRs and VPCs created outside of managed pools. Set up alerts for non-compliant allocations and implement remediation processes to bring them into compliance.

choices.title: Implement IP address capacity planning and forecasting

helpfulResource.displayText: Explore IPAM resource planning

improvementPlan.displayText: Regularly review IPAM pool utilization to forecast IP address consumption. Plan CIDR expansions proactively and establish processes for requesting additional address space before pools are exhausted.
